title: Shooting messengers like Dr. Anthony Fauci won’t win the war on COVID-19
summary:
There is no more trusted infectious-disease expert in the world than Fauci.
And trust, based on sometimes unwelcome scientific facts, is our greatest ally in the fight against this pandemic.
Instead of shooting the messenger, we should be listening to experts like Fauci and Birx and understanding that we will win this fight.
Not by political sniping or pitting some members of the White House task force against others.
But by analyzing real data as quickly, safely and scientifically as possible, and collectively adjusting our public-health strategies accordingly.

title: President Trump Approves Texas Disaster Declaration Related to COVID-19 Pandemic
summary:
President Donald Trump declared a major disaster exists in Texas related to the outbreak of novel coronavirus and ordered Federal assistance be sent to the Lone Star State.
“Texas is aggressively pursuing and implementing all necessary strategies to limit the impact of COVID-19, and I thank President Trump for his swift action to issue a Major Disaster Declaration for the State of Texas,” said Abbott in a statement Wednesday.
Additional federal funding is essential for us to maintain our aggressive course of action to protect our state."
Trump's action makes Federal funding available for crisis counseling, an area Abbott specifically requested assistance for, for affected individuals in all areas of Texas.
Federal funding is also available to state and eligible local governments and certain private nonprofit organizations for emergency protective measures, including direct Federal assistance, for all areas in the State of Texas impacted by COVID-19.

Median home sales prices fell in a few neighborhoods, including North Dallas, East Dallas and Far North Dallas.

title: Dallas-Fort Worth will have optimal viewing conditions for the first major meteor shower of 2020
summary:

The Quadrantids meteor shower will be the first major shower of 2020, according to the American Meteor Society.
North Texans interested in seeing the meteor shower will be in luck, as viewing conditions should be optimal.
Next year’s Quadrantids shower will happen during daylight hours for most of the U.S., limiting viewing options.
Timing and moonlight won’t be favorable for viewing in North America again until 2028, according to the meteor society.

title: Melissa Biller
summary:
Melissa Lawson Biller, 55, Okarche, died April 1, 2020.
She was born Feb. 23, 1965, in Chapel Hill, N.C., to Ken and Linda Watts Lawson.
Melissa worked as an emergency room RN in Denton Community Hospital in Denton, Texas, from 1992-1997 and at Ft. Walton Beach Community Hospital in Florida from 1997-2004.
Melissa was raised and achieved most of her dreams in big cities, but always knew her true self was in Okarche.
She is survived by her father; her husband of 35 years, Mark Biller; son Preston Biller and wife Sarah; daughter Katherine Waters and husband Chad; her super wonderful granddaughter Alicia Waters; brothers Ken and Henry Lawson; sisters Jennifer Longnecker and Hollie Howard; and lots of Billers, Lawsons and friends who will miss her.

title: 64 white supremacists in North Texas sentenced in federal investigation
summary:
Sixty-four people belonging to white supremacist gangs were sentenced recently to a combined 820 years in federal prison, the U.S. attorney’s office for the Northern District of Texas announced Friday.
The mass sentencing caps an investigation that began in 2014 and included 153 total defendants tied to white supremacist gangs, said Erin Dooley, spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney’s office.
In 2017, 89 of those defendants were convicted and sentenced to a combined 1,070 years in federal prison.
The last defendant in the second round, 51-year-old Garry Cody Jones, was sentenced Thursday to more than 11 years in federal prison on a drug charge.
In addition to drug and firearms charges, several defendants kidnapped, threatened and assaulted people who they believed had stolen drug money.

title: Austin housing market starting to feel coronavirus effects
summary:

Vaike O’Grady, regional director in Austin for Metrostudy, which tracks the housing market, said "we are just starting to see the impact" of the coronavirus on residential real estate.
"The fundamentals of the Austin market (including job and population growth) are strong, but we’ve never faced a situation like this before," O’Grady said.

title: Coronavirus Transforming Jails Across the Country
summary:
Across the country, the coronavirus outbreak is transforming criminal justice in the most transient and turbulent part of the system: local jails.
Run mostly by county sheriffs, jails hold an ever-changing assortment of people—those who are awaiting trial and cannot afford to pay bail; those convicted of low-level offenses; overflows from crowded prisons.
Quarantines are also underway in Silicon Valley, where a public defender who visited a Santa Clara County jail tested positive for coronavirus.
“It’s amazing,” said Sarah Wood, a lawyer and policy director at the Harris County Public Defender’s Office.
The state prison system has already stopped taking in new prisoners, so now those with recent criminal convictions must wait at county jails.

title: Has Dallas-Fort Worth seen its last freeze of the season?
summary:
Lows in the 30s aren’t in the forecast for Dallas-Fort Worth in the near future, and, historically, the average date of the last freeze — March 12 — is near.
On average, Dallas-Fort Worth gets about two freezes in the month of March.
Dallas-Fort Worth has recorded a freeze as late into the year as April 13, which has happened in 1997 and 1957, according to the National Weather Service.
Last year, Dallas-Fort Worth got its last freeze of the season on March 6, according to the weather service.
So, I think our chance for another freeze is very low.”In 2017, Dallas-Fort Worth recorded the earliest last freeze of the season on Jan. 8, when the temperature dropped to 20 degrees.

title: Coronavirus concern, price war drives Texas gas prices to lowest level in more than a year
summary:
Gas prices across Texas are reaching lows not seen in more than a year as concerns about the coronavirus impact coupled with price wars between top producers have caused crude oil prices to plummet.
“Texas gas prices are at their cheapest point in more than a year,” AAA Texas spokesperson Joshua Zuber said in a statement Thursday.
The average gas price in Texas is $2.01 per gallon, even lower than the national average of $2.32 per gallon, according to AAA.
If crude oil prices remain at current levels, AAA predicts drivers will continue to see low prices at the pump.
The lowest gas prices in the Dallas-Fort Worth metro Thursday morning were at Love’s, Brookshire’s and Valero in Bridgeport, where gas is $1.65 per gallon, according to GasBuddy.com.

Democratic primary turnout among registered voters peaked in 2008 at 22.5% during Barack Obama’s historic presidential bid, though in other years the Democrats have drawn fewer than 10 percent of primary voters.
Meanwhile, North Texas Republicans say they’re still happy with turnout during a primary with fewer contested Republican races.

title: With $2 billion in losses, Dallas-area tornadoes are North Texas’ costliest weather event, insurance council says
summary:
The Insurance Council of Texas has estimated about $2 billion in insured losses as a result of Sunday’s nine tornadoes across North Texas.
That would mean the tornadoes are the costliest severe weather event in North Texas’ history, said Camille Garcia, a spokeswoman for the Insurance Council of Texas.
For comparison, the tornadoes that devastated Rowlett and Garland in 2015, killing several people, clocked in at $1.2 billion in insured losses.
In addition to leveling homes across the area, the storms caused “a host of commercial property damage,” which is one of the reasons why these storms are estimated to be more expensive than the 2015 tornadoes, Garcia said.
She called the $2 billion number, which is for damage wrought by all nine twisters, a “pretty conservative estimate.”

title: Arctic cold front headed for Dallas-Fort Worth will drop temperatures into the 20s
summary:
After mild weather this weekend, temperatures in Dallas-Fort Worth are expected to plunge into the 20s.
A strong cold front is forecast to move through North Texas on Monday, according to KXAS-TV (NBC5) meteorologist Grant Johnston.
Any rain is expected to end before temperatures start to drop, preventing the chance for any wintry precipitation in Dallas-Fort Worth, according to Matt Stalley, a weather service meteorologist.
Some portions of Dallas-Fort Worth could see wind chills drop into the single digits and teens by Tuesday morning, said Steve Fano, a weather service meteorologist.
With wind gusts up to 50 mph possible, the weather service issued a wind advisory for most of North Texas, including Dallas-Fort Worth.

title: Tarrant County saw the biggest home price gains in November
summary:
Tarrant County topped North Texas in home price increases in November.
Median home sales prices in Tarrant County were up 7.6% from November 2018 levels, according to the MetroTex Association of Realtors.
For all of North Texas, the median price of single-family homes sold by real estate agents rose 4% from a year earlier.
Home sales in November were down 1% in Collin County — the only area among seven North Texas counties that saw a decline from 2018.
The biggest home sales increases were in Kaufman County (up 22.9%) and Ellis County (up 7.4%).

title: Brrrrr… North Texas Braces For Below Freezing Overnight Temperatures
summary:
NORTH TEXAS (CBSDFW.COM) – North Texas is preparing for the coldest dose of weather yet this season as an arctic front heads our way for Veterans Day.
The front brings a sharp and sudden temperature drop, gusty north winds, and a slight chance for rain followed by our first hard freeze of the season.
North winds gusting up to 40-45 mph will send wind chill values into the 20s Monday afternoon and into the teens overnight.
To account for the extreme wind, a Wind Advisory is in effect for all of North Texas Monday morning through Tuesday morning.
The cold weather will make it feel like we’re in the end of winter rather than late fall.

title: Firefighters subdue four-alarm warehouse blaze in Dallas’ Fair Park area
summary:
It took more than 100 Dallas firefighters to subdue a four-alarm fire that sent smoke billowing across Interstate 30 near Fair Park, slowing traffic in the area.
Crews were dispatched about 5:41 p.m. to a food distribution warehouse in the 1800 block of Chestnut Street after multiple 911 calls, Dallas Fire-Rescue spokesman Jason Evans said.
The blaze, just south of I-30 near the Austin Street Shelter, was listed as a two-alarm fire at the time.
When firefighters arrived, they saw flames erupting from the side of the large structure, Evans said.
Crews attempted to initiate an offensive attack, but with the fire well advanced, commanders pulled crews back and upgraded the blaze to a second-alarm fire.

title: North Texas home sales inched ahead in November
summary:
North Texas home sales edged higher in November, but the year-over year rate of increase tapered off from previous months.
Preowned home sales by real estate agents rose by 2% from November 2018 levels, according to a new report from the Real Estate Center at Texas A&M University and the North Texas Real Estate Information Systems.
Real estate agents sold 7,711 houses through their multiple listing service in November.
Through the first 11 months of 2019, North Texas home sales by real estate agents have risen 2% from the same period last year.
More than 23,000 single-family homes were listed for sale in the more than two dozen North Texas counties included in the survey — 2% less than in November 2018.

title: Census: Texas Counties Saw Large Population Gains Over Past Decade
summary:
Six of the 10 U.S. counties with the largest population gains this decade were in Texas, according to the U.S. Census Bureau’s July 1, 2019, population estimates released this week.
“One interesting trend we have seen this decade is widespread population decline among smaller counties, while larger counties tended to have population growth,” Christine Hartley, a demographer in the Census Bureau’s Population Division, said.
“Three out of four counties with a population of less than 10,000 in 2010 had even smaller populations in 2019.
At the same time, three out of four counties of 50,000 or more were larger in 2019 compared to 2010.”The pattern among larger counties is particularly evident in the West and South.
Vintage 2019 is the last series of population estimates to be released before the 2020 Decennial Census is completed.

title: CerSci Therapeutics Provides Clinical and Corporate Update
summary:

The primary objective of the Phase I studies was to investigate the safety and tolerability of CT-044 in healthy volunteers.
In addition, CerSci has completed dosing for a food effect study of CT-044 on ten volunteers in both fed and fasted states.
Once CerSci has completed all required Phase 1 studies, the company plans to proceed with proof-of-concept Phase 2 trials.
CerSci's novel clinical candidate, CT-044, is designed as an orally bioavailable compound that will initially target post-operative and chronic neuropathic pain indications.

title: See what the path of Dallas’ EF-3 tornado looks like from space
summary:
An EF-3 tornado that struck North Texas in October created such widespread damage that its path can be seen from space.
A new image taken Dec. 6 from the International Space Station captured all of Dallas-Fort Worth, including several lakes, DFW International Airport and everything in between.
Upon zooming in, the image also shows the more than 15-mile path of the Oct. 20 tornado from northwest Dallas into Richardson.
Several bodies of water are pictured including Joe Pool Lake, Mountain Creek Lake, White Rock Lake, Lake Ray Hubbard, Lewisville Lake and Grapevine Lake among others.
The Dallas tornado topped out at EF-3 but its power ebbed and flowed during its 32-minute track.

title: The Texas economy added almost 1,000 jobs a day in 2019
summary:
Texas employers created 28,900 new jobs in December, even as the state’s unemployment rate crept up slightly, according to data released Friday by the Texas Workforce Commission.
For the year, the state’s labor force grew by 342,800 jobs — the equivalent of nearly 1,000 new jobs a day.
The state added 391,800 jobs in 2018.
The Dallas-Fort Worth area’s unemployment rate fell to 2.9%, down from November’s 3%.
Midland once again recorded the lowest unemployment rate in the state at 2.1% for December, followed by Amarillo’s 2.3%.

title: Dallas has had 200 murders in 2019. Here’s what that means.
summary:
Police consider 200 of the deaths murders and 10 of them justifiable homicides, on which grand juries are asked to weigh in.
This far into 2018, Dallas had recorded 169 homicides, including those considered justifiable homicides, according to federally reported data published Thursday by Dallas police.
Among the 200, 190 are murders in which the incident and death occurred in 2019.
What is clear is that the last time Dallas recorded 200 murders was in 2007.
Other things also stand out in Dallas’ numbers: Homicides involving a gun have increased 32% from a year ago, to 167.

title: North Texas home sales set record in 2019
summary:
North Texas’ housing market ended 2019 on a high note, and the jump in sales during the final month was enough to push the year’s home purchases to an all-time high.
Area real estate agents sold more than 108,000 single-family homes for the year — 3% more than in 2018, according to preliminary data from the Real Estate Center at Texas A&M University and North Texas Real Estate Information Systems.
“Dallas-Fort Worth winds up with record sales again,” said James Gaines, chief economist for the Real Estate Center.
For all of 2019, North Texas home prices were 3% ahead of those in 2018, according to the Real Estate Center.
There are indications that January will be another strong month for North Texas home purchases.

title: Here’s how warm it’ll be in Dallas-Fort Worth on Christmas Day
summary:
Temperatures in Dallas-Fort Worth are expected to be above normal through the weekend, according to KXAS-TV (NBC5) weather anchor Keisha Burns.
During this time of the year, Dallas-Fort Worth typically sees highs in the mid-50s, according to the National Weather Service.
The warmest Christmas Day on record in Dallas-Fort Worth happened in 2016, when the high topped out at 80 degrees, according to the Weather Service.
It’s "looking pretty quiet for the next several days before changes happen,” Burns said of this week’s forecast in Dallas-Fort Worth.
Meanwhile, portions of Nevada, Utah, Colorado, Montana and Wyoming could be due for a White Christmas, according to Weather Service forecasts.

title: Man Charged With Murder for Deadly Late December Dallas Shooting
summary:
Dallas police made an arrest Sunday in connection to a shooting that left a 21-year-old man dead in late December.
Officers arrested 22-year-old Fernando Mancha on Sunday and charged him with murder after he waived his Miranda rights and admitted his involvement in the shooting that killed Patrick Lynn Parks III to detectives, Dallas police said.
The shooting happened Dec. 26 around 9 p.m. in the 3000 block of Falls Drive in Oak Cliff, police said.
Officers responded to a call for shots fired and people fighting, and found Parks dead on the sidewalk from a gunshot would, police said.
Mancha's bond will be set by a magistrate, police said.

title: Arrest made in fatal December shooting at northwest Dallas motel
summary:
Updated at 6:15 p.m. Jan. 2: Revised to reflect an arrest in the case.
Police have made an arrest in a shooting that left one man dead and two others wounded Monday morning in northwest Dallas.
Cameron Blakely (Dallas County Sheriff's Department)Officers were called just before 7 a.m. to a motel in the 2600 block of Royal Lane, near Interstate 35E, where they found 34-year-old Kerry Jones dead inside a room.
Two other men were found with multiple gunshot wounds: 37-year-old Michael Rosa was lying on the motel-room floor near the door, and 27-year-old Cameron Blakely was outside near the motel entrance.
Blakely, who also faces a drug-possession charge, was being held in the Dallas County jail.

title: Could it be a snowy winter for Dallas-Fort Worth? Here’s what the new Farmer’s Almanac says
summary:
As warm weather lingers over North Texas, it might be hard to believe that winter is coming.
The 2020 edition of The Old Farmer's Almanac predicts a milder, drier winter than normal for portions of Texas and Oklahoma, but it's not counting out a chance for snow.
The almanac predicts the best chances for snow in Oklahoma and North Texas, including Dallas-Fort Worth, are in early December, early to mid-January and mid-February.
North Texas saw its first snowflakes of 2019 on Jan. 19.
The almanac also predicts the coldest periods of the winter will arrive in late December, late January and mid-February.

title: Operation Christmas Gift 2019 to Help Thousands of Homeless and Less Fortunate Families
summary:
A few days before Christmas, the homeless and less fortunate in Dallas-Fort Worth are being invited to a birthday party for Jesus.
It's called Operation Christmas Gift 2019, and it will be held Saturday Dec. 21 at the Dallas Convention Center.
It's all being put on by Susie Jennings, the founder and president of Operation Care International.
The event will be from 8:30 a.m. to 3 p.m.A few thousand homeless children are also expected at the event.
The organization still needs donations of children's coats, athletic shoes, toys or money.

“It’s not uncommon for it to be higher in November or even April,” she said of flu activity.

title: Here’s what winter could look like for Dallas-Fort Worth without an El Niño or La Niña
summary:
An outlook issued by the National Weather Service expects conditions to stay neutral in the Pacific Ocean this winter, meaning neither an El Niño nor a La Niña is expected to form.
Temperatures in the area could be warmer than normal, based on a recent trend of warmer winters, according to the weather service.
If you missed it earlier this week, the 2019-20 NOAA #Winter Outlook was issued.
The outlook says excessive rainfall events are less likely, and it calls for near-normal amounts of snowfall and winter weather events.
The last time Dallas-Fort Worth saw significant snowfall was 3.5 inches in March 2015, according to the weather service.

title: Brief periods of heavy rain strike Dallas-Fort Worth, but nothing severe
summary:
Saturday brought warmer-than-usual temperatures and brief smatterings of heavy rain — but no damage — in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

The rain did leave a lasting impression on flights to an from DFW International Airport.
The forecast indicated that a few areas could see some hail, but none developed, Ryan said.

summary:
A strong cold front is expected to move through Dallas-Fort Worth by Monday afternoon, according to KXAS-TV (NBC5) meteorologist Grant Johnston.
“Perhaps even here in Dallas-Fort Worth, a few wet snowflakes may mix in.”Little to no snow accumulations are expected, according to the National Weather Service.
For Dallas-Fort Worth, there is only the potential for a “dusting of snow," Johnston said.
Because ground temperatures have been warm, widespread travel issues are not expected, according to Johnston.
After Tuesday, expect highs in the 50s and lows in the 30s through the weekend, according to Burns.

title: Riding the energy wave
summary:
In late 2019, production levels in the Permian reached 4.7 million bpd and 17 billion ft3/d of gas.
In mid-2019, Energy Transfer Partners announced plans to build a Very Large Crude Carrier (VLCC) terminal at its existing facilities in Nederland, Texas.
The 2.2 billion ft3/d line is now moving gas from the Permian Basin to the Houston region, Texas.
To feed the project, Enbridge will build the Rio Bravo, a 4.5 billion ft3/d gas pipeline from Agua Dulce to Brownsville.
US offshoreAccording to the EIA, crude output in the US Gulf offshore now sits at 2 million bpd, rising over 100 000 bpd in the last year.

title: Bar Raised: Dallas Spent $82M On Booze In December ’19.
authors: President Of Central Track. He Is The Former Music Editor Of The Dallas Observer. His Work Has Been Published In The Daily Beast
summary:
A Breakdown Of How Much Money Was Spent On Booze At The Top Bars, Clubs, Restaurants, Venues And Hotels Within Dallas Proper In December 2019.
Soon as Dallas’ bar sales figures for November were posted last month, we knew there was a better-than-zero chance that the amount of money spent on booze in the city in 2019 was going to top 2018’s $898,384,011 total.
For now, though, let’s just look at what this month’s nearly $82 million in Dallas alcohol sales represents.
For starters, it’s worth noting that it was the third-highest bar sales month of the year, trailing only March’s $85.1 million total and October’s $82.4 million figure.
The only moderate surprise here, we’d say, is the slightly stronger-than-usual hotel bar sales — although that much seems like it could be logically chalked up to the holiday season, somehow.

title: What happened to Big D NYE? Curious Texas investigates
summary:
From 2007 to 2014, tens of thousands of people gathered to ring in the new year outside American Airlines Center at one of the biggest parties in North Texas: Big D NYE.
So Jess asked Curious Texas: “What happened to Big D NYE?”In January 2015, the partnership between WFAA and American Airlines Center dissolved, leaving the event without a venue.
The American Airlines Center holds about 18,500 people for Stars games, and in 2014 about 42,000 people attended Big D NYE.
As for Big D NYE’s future, Glass said via email that there are no plans for a return.
So how have North Texans been ringing in the new year since Big D NYE’s confirmed permanent departure?

title: 1 dead after shooting in Vickery Meadow neighborhood of northeast Dallas
summary:
A man is dead after a shooting Sunday afternoon in the Vickery Meadow neighborhood of northeast Dallas.
Officers were called about 1:40 p.m. to the scene of the shooting in the 7000 block of Hemlock Avenue, near Park Lane, according to police call records.
Police said the victim, identified Monday as 22-year-old Mohamed Abdi Mohamed, had been arguing with someone at the 24 Hours Store on Park Lane before another person shot him.
Police said Mohamed was wearing a camouflage jacket and that he did not have any identification on his person.
Anyone with information about the shooting may contact Detective Esteban Montenegro at 214-671-3624 or at e.montenegro@dallascityhall.com and refer to case number 246477-2019.

title: Risks to Texas Prosperity in 2020 and Beyond
summary:
The Texas economy is probably strong enough to shake off some potential shocks—just as it did with the 2014 plunge in oil prices.
It’s not hard, though, to envision scenarios that would set Texas’ economy reeling.
Texas needs more of these workers, especially the highly skilled, and Trump’s across-the-board hostility to immigrants threatens to weaken the state’s economy.
The Bottom LineSome of the threats to Texas’ economy may not amount to much as events move forward, and others might prove more ominous than they appear today.
None of the risks are immediate, and the Texas and DFW economies are likely to continue growing in 2020, perhaps at a slightly slower pace.

Main threats: gusty winds, small hail and frequent lightning.
After a few days this week with above-normal temperatures, the front will bring Dallas-Fort Worth down to more normal levels for this time of year.

title: Even a tornado couldn’t ruin Christmas for this Dallas toy store
summary:
The holiday season looked pretty dire for The Toy Maven in late October, but there’s a happy ending to this Christmas shopping story.
Candace Williams, owner of The Toy Maven, photographed at a temporary location of the store at Preston and Forest.

Last week, a new toy store called Camp opened in The Hill shopping center in Dallas at N. Central Expressway north of Walnut Hill Lane.

title: Dallas’ New Virgin Hotel Debuts Sunday
summary:
After years of planning and construction, the nation’s third Virgin Hotel opens Sunday in Dallas' Design District.
Developer Bill Hutchinson said the Virgin brand and the Design District location elevated expectations for the 268-room hotel.
So that Virgin Hotel, I think, will be the most exciting hotel in the whole city,” Hutchinson said.
But that comes with a price.”Virgin Hotel Opens Sunday in Dallas’ Design DistrictWhat was to be a $110 million project rose to $120 million as Hutchinson added more features.
NBC 5 NewsThe distinctive white building has a lattice work design that creates shadow effects inside.

title: Family Says 12-Year-Old Boy Sacrificed Himself to Save Mom From Speeding Van
summary:
We’re learning more about a 12-year-old boy who was killed while walking, two days before Christmas.
The family said Victor was walking with his mom and 7-year-old nephew when he was hit.
The driver of the van told police he swerved to avoid a vehicle that suddenly stopped in front of him.

The scheduled route for the 2019 BMW Dallas Marathon.

title: Countdown to 2020 Fireworks at Reunion Tower
summary:
Cases of fireworks and computer equipment arrived at Reunion Tower to make the trip to the top.
"This is what we call the lower roof," Melrose Pyrotechnics Creative Director Matt Peterson said, standing 500 feet above the street on the deck outside the Reunion Tower ball.
The New Year's Eve fireworks will go off from all around the Reunion Tower ball.
"This one ranks number 1," Peterson said about the Reunion Tower display.
2018 went out with a bang in North Texas with plenty of big fireworks from the top of Reunion Tower in Dallas.

title: Explore This Updated Map of Dallas’ 2019 Homicides
summary:
We last brought you this map in June, shortly after the city’s spell of 40 murders in May, more than any month since the 1990s.
With Dallas closing out its most murderous year in a decade, and with Police Chief U. Reneé Hall and City Manager T.C.
Broadnax now working on a mayor-mandated plan of action to bring violence under control, it’s worth tossing to you again.
TheMap’s Robert Mundinger has pulled together every murder in the city, based on Dallas police data that is open to the public (it is unfortunately incomplete, but we get close).
Play around with the map here.

title: Where To Celebrate New Year’s Eve in Dallas
summary:
Hotel Crescent Court’s champagne bar Beau Nash has a New Year’s Eve Bash with DJ Ducati and specialty cocktails.
Crowne Plaza Hotel in Downtown Dallas will throw the 10th annual Dallas NYE Ball throughout three floors of the building.
Hero in Victory Park has a chill NYE party with lots of snacks, a 360 photo booth, and dancing.
Visit Dallas has a Party on the Plaza with Ron Corning at Dallas City Hall Plaza.
is having its Lone Star NYE Live celebration with live entertainment, a ball drop, casino games, and more.
